item.title: ISIS Captures Jordanian Fighter Pilot in Syria
item.description: The Jordanian military confirmed that one of its pilots had been taken hostage after reports that a jet was shot down in northern Syria.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Raqqa Media Center of the Islamic State group, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An image posted by the Islamic State purported to show militants with a captured Jordanian pilot in Raqqa, Syria, on Wednesday.

item.title: Shinzo Abe Begins New Term With Push to Revise Japan’s Constitution
item.description: Mr. Abe, leader of the Liberal Democratic Party, acknowledged that he faced a battle in convincing voters to change a constitution that renounces war.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Bits Blog: Uber C.E.O. Charged With Violating South Korea Transport Laws
item.description: Seoul prosecutors indicted Travis Kalanick, the ride booking company’s chief executive, as well as its local unit and car-rental partner, for violating taxi licensing laws.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: Travis Kalanick, chief executive of Uber, in Beijing last week.

item.title: The Big Fix: Restored Forests Breathe Life Into Efforts Against Climate Change
item.description: Driven by a growing environmental movement and mounting pressure from Western consumers, corporate and government leaders are making a new push to slow the cutting of rain forests.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS

item.title: Hong Kong Cash Spill Snarls Traffic as Motorists Scramble for Bills
item.description: With about $2 million worth of cash missing, the police warned bystanders who took advantage of the Christmas Eve windfall to return the snatched money.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Ukraine Briefly Cuts Power to Crimea Amid Dispute With Russia Over NATO
item.description: The electricity shutoff to the peninsula, annexed by Russia nine months ago, came as Russia warned Ukraine not to join the Western military alliance.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: India to Deploy 5,000 Troops to Assam After String of Attacks
item.description: The country’s northeast remained unstable after militants from the National Democratic Front of Bodoland, which seeks an independent state in Assam, opened fire in remote tribal villages.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Palestinian Sniper Attack on Israeli Patrol at Gaza Border Sets Off Clash
item.description: The Israelis responded with air and ground forces, in what appeared to be the most serious direct confrontation between Israel and Hamas since fighting ended in August.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Lens Blog: American Culture, Riding a Mushroom Cloud
item.description: In “Chewing Gum and Chocolate,” Shomei Tomatsu explored the attractions and contradictions of American culture and the military in postwar Japan.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MAURICE BERGER

item.title: World Briefing: India: Attacks Kill Villagers in Northeast
item.description: Militants in India’s northeastern state of Assam killed at least 33 people Tuesday, firing indiscriminately in attacks on remote tribal villages.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Raymond W. Baker on Financial Fraud in China
item.description: Between 2003 and 2012, $6.6 trillion was secretly and illegally funneled out of developing and emerging economies by entities that may have been involved in crime, corruption and tax evasion, according to one study.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: Algerian Army Kills Militant Leader Linked to Beheading of French Hostage
item.description: Two associates reportedly died with the leader, Abdelmalek Gouri, in an ambush about 50 miles from the capital.
item.dc:creator: By AMIR JALAL ZERDOUMI

item.title: News Analysis: Countering Cyberattacks Without a Playbook
item.description: Because there are no international treaties or norms about how to use digital weapons, there are no rules about how to fight conflicts like the one spawned by the digital attack on Sony Pictures.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Posters for “The Interview” in Los Angeles, pulled from theaters after North Korean threats.

item.title: Cuba’s Zeal for Tight Control Casts a Pall on New Markets
item.description: Raúl Castro’s decision to normalize relations was driven by economic interests, but his government seems intent on opening markets only a crack.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: A portrait of Che Guevara at a shop in Havana.

item.title: World Briefing: Ireland: Doctors Seek to Remove Pregnant Woman From Life Support
item.description: Doctors said the patient, in her late 20s, was declared clinically dead Dec. 3 after wounding her head in a fall on Nov. 29.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In About-Face, Sony Will Screen ‘The Interview’ in a Small Run
item.description: Sony also left open the door to video-on-demand availability of the movie, either simultaneously with its debut in theaters, or nearly so.
item.dc:creator: By BROOKS BARNES and MICHAEL CIEPLY
item.media:description: The Plaza theater in Atlanta is among the 200 smaller theaters so far that plans to show “The Interview” on Christmas Day.

item.title: After Long Fight, Groups Pry Memo on Migrant Killings From Mexican Government
item.description: In a small victory for transparency advocates, Mexico released a document from the attorney general’s office that describes police complicity in the killings of migrants by drug gangs.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Ukraine Vote Takes Nation a Step Closer to NATO
item.description: A parliamentary vote to pursue closer ties to the West drew a sharp rebuke from Russia, which called the step counterproductive.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: As Ruble Falters, Russia Forces Exporters to Reduce Foreign Currency
item.description: The announcement was the first open acknowledgment that the Kremlin would use its controlling votes on the boards of directors of major companies to force economic policy decisions.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: World Briefing: Hong Kong: 2 Sentenced in Graft Case
item.description: The former No. 2 official in the Hong Kong government was sentenced to seven and a half years in prison and a property tycoon to five years on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG
